person.occupation: Janissary (salaried soldier in the standing infantry corps), controller of the financial administration (muqābeleci)
person.death: in the last years of the reign of Sultan Murād III (1574-95)
person.note: Meḥemmed Kemālī Defterdār-zāde; further names given in 16th and 17th century sources: İsmāʿīl, İsmāʿīl Kemāleddīn, Balāṭī-zāde; writer of the mes̱nevī on the folios 31v-49v of this manuscript and probably the actual owner of this manuscript
Alias for an involved party occurring in a fatwa
Alias for an involved party occurring in a fatwa
Alias for an involved party occurring in a fatwa
Alias for an involved party occurring in various documents

person.occupation: the master of the standards, tents and the military band of the sultan (mīr‑i ʿalem), commander of the Janissary Corps (yeñiçeri aġası), governor general of Buda (beglerbegi), governor general of Rūmėli, grand vizier
person.note: aka: Yūsuf Paşa; cf. Selânikî Mustafa Efendi: Tarih-i Selânikî.
Yūsuf bin Yaʿqūb, Joseph; “…, in the Ḳurʾān and later Islamic literature parallels, the Joseph of the Hebrew Bible and Jewish and Christian tradition.” cf. EI2, s.v. Yūsuf .
Avicenna; cf. EI2, s.v. Ibn Sīnā.
Murād bin Selīm; Sultan Murād III
probable that he is the same Ḥasan Aġa who was a çavuş of the dīvān and later the commander of the çavuş of the dīvān (çavuş-başı) cf. Sicill‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 2, p. 606, s.v. Hasan Ağa.
also Nerīm; name of a famous hero of Persian legend, great-grandfather of Rustam
Cf. İpekten et al.: Tezkirelere Göre Divan Edebiyatı İsimler Sözlüğü. Ankara 1988, p. 133 (s.v. Fedâyî).

Cf. SO I, 50‑51. The poet is also known as Şarḫoş ʿAbdī and ʿAbdī Çelebi. This mes̱nevī is included in the chronicle of Selānikī (cf. İpşirli 1989: 519ff.) and has been published by Burian 1950 in a modern Turkish transcription with many omissions.
Sulaymān b. Dāwūd, the biblical King Soliman
Alexander the Great; Ẕū l‑Qarneyn “the two-horned”; cf. EI2, s.v. al-Iskandar.

person.occupation: Qoran commentator, Ḥanafī scholar, şeyḫü l‑islām

person.note: probably Kemāl Paşa‑zāde or İbn(‑i) Kemāl, cf. EI2, s.v. Kemāl Pasha-zāde.
correct version: Ḫıżr; cf. EI2, s.v. al-Khaḍir (al-Khiḍr).
Murād bin Selīm: Sultan Murād III.
Murād bin Selīm; Sultan Murād III.
Ġāzī Girāy II; cf. EI2, s.v. Ghāzī Girāy II.
Meḥemmed bin Murād; Sultan Meḥmed II.
identity is not determinable definitely; cf. İpekten et al.: Tezkirelere Göre Divan Edebiyatı İsimler Sözlüğü. Ankara 1988, p. 515: five poets with the penname Vāḥidī.
Cf. EI2, s.v. ʿAlī b. Abī Ṭālib; cousin and son-in-law of Muḥammad.
ʿUmar bin al‑Ḫaṭṭāb; cf. EI2, s.v. ʿUmar (I) b. al‑Khaṭṭāb.
“fallen angel or Djinn in the legendary tradition of Islam … He gets his name from the biblical ʿAzāzel …” cf. EI2, s.v. ʿAzāzīl.
his real name was probably Šams al-Dīn Muḥammad bin ʿAlī bin Malik‑dād‑i Tabrīzī; cf. EI2, s.v. Shams‑i Tabrīz(ī)
Jacob, son of Isaac, son of Abraham; cf. EI2, s.v. Yaʿḳūb.

person.occupation: Persian poet and founder of the Mawlawiyya order of dervishes
person.note: Celāleddīn Rūmī; cf. EI2, s.v. Djalāl al‑Dīn Rūmī.
father of Solomon (Sulaymān); cf. EI2, s.v. Dāwūd.
also Cibrīl, Hebrew Gabrīʾēl; cf. EI2, s.v. Djabrāʾīl.
also Cibrīl, Hebrew Gabrīʾēl; cf. EI2, s.v. Djabrāʾīl.
Cf. Sicill‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 1, p. 284, s.v. Ali Paşa (Elvendzâde).
Cf. EI2, s.v. Āṣāf b. Barakhyā.

cf. Sicilli‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 1, p. 213, s.v. Ahmed Paşa (Kara); İsmail Hâmi Danişmend: İzahlı Osmanlı Tarihi Kronolojisi 5: Osmalı Devlet Erkânı – Sadr-ı-A’zamlar (Vezir-i-A’zamlar), Şeyh-ül-İslâmlar, Kapdan-ı-Deryalar, Baş-Defterdarlar, Reîs-ül-Küttablar. İstanbul 1971, p. 18.
a king of Israel; son of Dāvūd; cf. EI2, s.v. Dāwūd.
identity is not determinable definitely; cf. Sicill‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 2, p. 381, s.v. Ca’fer Paşa

person.occupation: heir to the throne of the Crimean Khanate (qalġay)
person.note: Cf. EI2, s.v. Girāy; s.v. Ghāzī Girāy.

person.occupation: Grand vizier; governor general; fleet commander

Cf. Sicill-i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), p. 640, s.v. Hasan Paşa (Hadım) and p. 644, s.v. Hasan Paşa (Sokolluzâde).
Cf. Sicill‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 4, p. 1045, s.v. Mehmed Paşa (Cerrah).
Cf. Sicill‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 4, p. 1045, s.v. Mehmed Paşa (Cerrah).
Cf. Sicill‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 3, p. 922, s.v. Mahmud Paşa. This Maḥmūd Paşa was beglerbegi of Aleppo in 1593/94.
Dāmād İbrāhīm Paşa; cf. Sicill‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 3, p.778, s.v. İbrahim Paşa (Damad-ı Şehriyârî).
cf. Sicill‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 2, p. 367, s.v. Bektaş Paşa

known as Şeyḫ Saʿdī; cf. EI2, s.v. Saʿdī.

identity is not determinable definitely; probably a certain Ġubārī Maḥmūd Çelebi who lived during the reign of Murād III. (1574-1595); cf. Sicill‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 2, p. 549, s.v. Gubârî Mahmud Çelebi (Kerestecizâde).
identity is not determinable definitely; cf. Procházka-Eisl (2010): p. 152.
according to TGDEİS, p. 46 born in Edirne. Cf. Sicill‑i ʿOs̱mānī (1996), 1, p.328, s.v. Askerî Çelebi.

capital and largest city of Serbia

150 km north from Belgrade, on the bank if the Tisa river, in the province Vojvodina
name applied to the territories of the lower Roman Empire, the Seljuqi kingdom and to the Ottoman Empire

in Baranya county, on the right bank of the Danube
conquered by the Ottomans many times; this chronogram refers to the conquest of 1585 during the reign of Murād III. (1574-1595); cf. EI2, s.v. Tabrīz.
“east of Mecca, on the road to Ṭāʾif”, Djabal al-Raḥma; cf. EI2, s.v. ʿArafa

“a place in the hills east of Mecca on the road from it to ʿArafa...”; cf. EI2, s.v. Minā.

location.country: Lebanon, Israel, Palestinian territories, Jordan, Syria

Ayn Sulwan; the well of Siloam

region of eastern Caucasia; cf. EI2, s.v. Shīrwān.
region around Central Asia; “In Firdawsī’s epic, Tūrān refers to the land to the north-east of Īrān…”; cf. EI2, s.v. Tūrān.
Eastern Turkey; cf. EI2, s.v. Kars.
capital of Georgia; cf. EI2, s.v. Tiflīs.

Murādīye, Yeñi Cāmiʿ, Cāmiʿ‑i Kebīr; cf. EI2, s.v. Edirne.
“The country of the Franks”, Europe, outside of Turkey; cf. Redhouse, s.v. Firengistān.

ḥabs‑i bevl

cit.sense: Bubo; Swelling of the lymph nodes

quatrain; any poem with the rhyme scheme ax ax ax …

cit.sense: historical and panegyrical long epic poem or prose work in praise of Selīm I. (1512-1520).

Lesser dodder Turkish: Bostanbozan, Cinsaçı, Eftimon, Gelinsaçı
Dried immature fruit of Terminalia chebula
Fruit of the golden shower tree
Balsam of Mecca; Balsam of Gilead
